Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Community and Demography in Bronze Age Southern Russia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Bryan Hanks, doctoral candidate, James A. Johnson, will analyze data collected during systematic pedestrian survey of and between the Middle Bronze Age (MBA) (2100 - 1700 BC) fortified settlements of Stepnoye and Chernorech'ye in the Chelyabinsk Oblast in southern Russia. This region has drawn increased attention of regional and international scholars due to the development of twenty-two fortified settlements in what had long been considered a predominately mobile pastoralist region. The fortified settlements are notable due to the similarity in spatial organization and the lack of differentiation in sizes between household structures. In addition, scholars have posited that some, if not all, of these settlements acted as centers for metallurgical production, indicative of not only demographic, but also economic and political centralization. Yet, no studies have been undertaken to actively test if these communities were centralized and if they were, to what degree.

Research focusing on the spatial relationships between centers and hinterlands is important as it will contribute vital information to a basic foundation of community social organization and demography shared across geographic regions. Broader social, economic and political processes common to anthropological archaeology such as social inequality, urbanization, and societal collapse cannot be empirically modeled without first developing a better understanding of the community dynamics involved. A logical starting place for such models is to empirically evaluate changes in local and regional demography. The evaluation of demographic changes in community spatial organization (through demographic distribution and density) can indicate the emergence and strength of centripetal trends that coincide with the development of social stratification, and might also reveal changes in human-environment relationships. Furthermore, systematic pedestrian survey can reveal the extent and the intensity to which centralized communities disintegrate and go on to form smaller, more mobile pastoral groups in post-collapse contexts. Documenting such patterns has long been a methodological and theoretical concern in anthropological archaeology and studies of early forms of social complexity, and in particular, early processes of urbanization. This project utilizes data gleaned from surface collections on changes in demographic distributions and densities to further evaluate the changing relationships between centers and their hinterlands as well as sedentary and more mobile groups.

Beyond the more specific research questions pertaining to anthropological archaeology, this project seeks to further develop international ties between Russian and American scholarly communities. Working closely with faculty from various Russian academic institutions, as well as Russian and American students from numerous universities, the project seeks to further bring Russian prehistory within the comparative lens of scientific research on the development of early forms of social complexity. By incorporating graduate and undergraduate students from both the US and Russian Federation, and encouraging the training of these students in new field methods, the project will help to overcome traditional obstacles between the two national archaeological traditions. Furthermore, the preparation of databases for publication on the University of Pittsburgh Center for Comparative Archaeology website will allow students and other scholars open access to view and utilize data collected from this research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation provided funding through a Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant for the co-PI’s doctoral research and field project on the emergence of demographically and politically centralized societies in the Middle to Final Bronze Ages (3300 – 900 BC) in the southern Urals of the Russian Federation. The project focused on the Ui River Valley in the Chelyabinsk Oblast', in particular around and between two Middle Bronze Age Sintashta fortified settlements (Stepnoye and Chernorech’ye). This prehistoric development (2100 – 1700 BC) has generated intense discussion among Russian and international scholars over the nature of social and political complexity of these early societies and what has been characterized as "proto-urban" transitions. The Sintashta settlement patterning is unique for this region during the Bronze Age and Sintashta communities have been modeled as demographic centers with potentially robust hinterland populations.

The intellectual merits of the doctoral research are represented by the project's aims to  answer specific questions about the demographic character of the Sintashta development, and later developments, as well as to target broader concerns about the nature of centralization in prehistoric pastoraist communities in the Eurasian steppe. The project introduced a new field methodology to this region (systematic regional pedestrian survey and surface collection) and built productively off the ongoing Sintashta Collaborative Archaeological Research Project (SCARP), which has also been funded by the National Science Foundation (Award numbers: 1024674 & 0726279). The project also produced new data through the survey and surface collection of artifacts that can be used to better understand the development and decline of not only the Sintashta communities, but also pastoralist communities in the Late and Final Bronze Ages. This research has yielded the following conclusions: 1) that demographic centralization began with the emergence of Middle Bronze Age Sintashta fortified settlements (ca. 2100 BC) and went through a steady case of decline as Late and Final Bronze Age groups became increasingly decentralized. However, overall population distributions and densities appear to have remained fairly steady with population numbers in the valley not changing significantly between the Middle, Late and Final Bronze Ages. Also, for the  Middle Bronze Age, there is little evidence for a robust hinterland in connection with fortified Sintashta settlements, however, in later periods there is more evidence for hinterland occupation; 2) that better demographic estimates can be generated using a combination of density-area indices of surface scatters that can be used to better evaluate the strength of centralization in pastoral communities; 3) that through the spatial patterning of occupation areas between the Middle Bronze Age and later settlements that some form of ‘buffering’ was possible that may have represented social and political tensions between pastoralist communities in the Ui River Valley; 4) that there appears to be little to no correlation with known economic or resource zones, but rather settlement patterning appears to have been social/political in nature; and 5) that Middle Bronze Age Sintashta communities appear to have settled in non-densely occupied landscapes rather than having been ‘local’ developments, i.e., local populations nucleating. Furthermore, Late and Final Bronze communities appear to have become increasingly decentralized, but still with visible forms of political centralization/authority appearing in certain types of pottery production styles/techniques, for example, uses of tempers and decorations.
